items.title: Samsung Galaxy S25 series launches with AI enhancements
items.summary:
- Samsung has launched its Galaxy S25 series, including S25, S25+, and S25 Ultra, priced at US$799, US$999, and US$1,299 respectively.
- Preorders started on Jan. 22, and the official availability is set for Feb. 7.
- The S25 series features advanced AI capabilities for multitasking and compatibility with apps like Spotify, WhatsApp, and Google services.
- Devices are powered by the Qualcomm Snapdragon 8 Elite processor for better AI performance and energy efficiency.
- The release comes amid a 2.7% year-on-year decline in smartphone shipments for Samsung in Q4 2024.
- Despite strong competition, analysts note that AI may not significantly drive consumer interest due to incremental upgrades.

items.title: Microsoft’s business development head Chris Young resigns
items.summary:
- Chris Young, Microsoft’s head of business development, resigns after nearly four years, disclosed on Jan. 22.
- Microsoft has not announced a successor for Young.
- He joined Microsoft in 2020 after serving as CEO of McAfee.
- Young reported directly to CEO Satya Nadella and was part of the senior leadership team.
- He led Microsoft's corporate venture capital arm, M12, investing in startups like Innovaccer, PsiQuantum, and Typeface.

items.title: Israeli AI startup Gong signs lease for $8.4m new facility
items.summary:
- Gong, an Israeli AI startup, signs a lease for a new facility valued at $8.4 million.
- The new facility is part of Gong's expansion efforts in the tech industry.
- This move reflects growth and increased investment in technology sectors in Israel.

items.title: Indian fintech startup Jar turns cash flow positive
items.summary:
- Bengaluru-based fintech startup Jar has confirmed it is now cash flow positive.
- This milestone highlights Jar's growth in its savings and investment platform over three years.
- Backed by Tiger Global, Jar reportedly grew over tenfold in the past year.
- The company has expanded offerings including lending services and an online jewelry segment named Nek, generating approximately US$13 million in annual sales.

items.title: TikTok deal in US expected soon: Bytedance board member
items.author: Bill Ford
items.summary:
- Bill Ford, CEO of General Atlantic and ByteDance board member, states a TikTok resolution in the US is expected soon.
- President Trump set a 75-day timeframe for negotiations to address national security concerns.
- Ford believes a deal is in everyone's interest and negotiations could start by week's end.
- Potential solutions may not require TikTok's divestiture.

items.title: Microsoft no longer exclusive cloud provider for OpenAI
items.summary:
- Microsoft is no longer the exclusive cloud provider for OpenAI as of January 23.
- Microsoft retains a "right of first refusal" for any additional capacity requests from OpenAI.
- The announcement coincides with the launch of the Stargate Project involving OpenAI, Oracle, and SoftBank.
- The Stargate Project includes an initial investment commitment of US$100 billion to expand AI infrastructure.

items.title: Hindustan Unilever to acquire Indian skincare startup
items.summary:
- Hindustan Unilever plans to acquire Jaipur-based skincare brand Minimalist for approximately US$342 million.
- The deal includes a 90.5% stake through secondary buyouts and primary investments; the remaining 9.5% will be purchased from the founders within two years.
- The transaction is expected to be finalized by the June quarter, pending regulatory approvals.
- This acquisition aims to strengthen Hindustan Unilever’s presence in the premium skincare market, complementing brands like Dove, Pond’s, and Lakmé.

items.title: Mirage or manna: Asia’s tech IPO hopes swell in 2025
items.summary:
- Past IPO predictions in Asia often felt like a mirage, with 2024 seeing a 35% decline in deals and a 51% drop in proceeds compared to 2023.
- Bright spots for 2025 include potential IPOs from SCI Ecommerce valued at over US$1 billion and Superbank looking to raise between US$200 million and US$300 million.
- Analysts expect more successful IPOs in 2025, particularly from the fintech and ecommerce sectors, with India and China showing stronger appetite for new listings.

items.title: Capital SEA: Southeast Asia’s funding landscape
items.author: Terence Lee, Yeo Cheng Yong
items.summary:
• The article explores the funding landscape in Southeast Asia, addressing who the new investors are and how investment trends have shifted over time.
• It is divided into two sections: weekly updates on notable investors and recent data points, and macro trends detailing the spread of funding across countries and stages.
• Access to the full report, including charts and visuals, requires a subscription.

items.title: Hong Kong discusses stablecoin bill, crypto licensing
items.summary:
- Hong Kong's Legislative Council discussed the proposed “Stablecoins Bill” on Jan. 23, marking the first meeting since its initial reading on Dec. 18, 2024.
- The bill requires issuers to obtain licenses from the Hong Kong Monetary Authority (HKMA) and maintain reserves in high-quality, highly liquid assets.
- The legislation aims to enhance compliance and stability, supporting Hong Kong’s strategy to attract international cryptocurrency firms.
- A subcommittee also reviewed the licensing framework for crypto trading platforms on the same day.

items.title: Nvidia leads market value, surpasses Apple
items.summary:
- Nvidia became the world's most valuable publicly traded company on Jan. 23, surpassing Apple in market value.
- On Jan. 23, Nvidia's market capitalization reached approximately US$3.45 trillion, with a 2% increase in shares.
- In 2024, Nvidia's stock increased by 171%, and in 2023 by nearly 239%, fueled by high demand for AI-focused chips.
- Apple's shares fell by 3%, leading to a market valuation of US$3.35 trillion, and its stock is down 11% in 2025 after gaining 30% in 2024.
- Apple lacks Nvidia's extensive exposure to the rapidly growing AI sector despite adding AI features to its products.

items.title: Israeli healthtech firm Eleos nets $60m series C
items.author: Alon Joffe, Dror Zaide, Alon Rabinovich
items.summary:
- Eleos Health raises US$60 million in series C funding led by Greenfield Partners.
- Other investors include F-Prime Capital, Eight Roads, Lool Ventures, Menlo Ventures, ION, and new contributors like the Michael & Susan Dell Foundation, Union Tech Ventures, and Centerstone.
- Total funding for Eleos now exceeds US$120 million.
- The company focuses on behavioral health technology powered by AI, founded in 2020.
- Funds will be used to expand offerings, enhance the commercial team, and address underserved areas in behavioral healthcare.

items.title: S Korean food delivery app cuts restaurant commission fees
items.summary:
- Baedal Minjok (Baemin) to change commission fee structure effective Feb. 26, 2025.
- New commission rates will range from 2% to 7.8%, reduced from 9.8%.
- Aimed at alleviating financial pressure on small businesses due to ingredient costs and inflation.
- Changes follow an agreement with the government, delivery platforms, and restaurant associations.
- Baemin 1 Plus subscribers' delivery fees will be adjusted based on sales performance.

items.title: LinkedIn appoints new chief AI officer
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Deepak Agarwal has rejoined LinkedIn as its chief AI officer, marking his second term with the company.
- Previously spent about eight years at LinkedIn as vice president of AI and engineering.
- Agarwal has over 24 years of experience in AI and has held leadership roles at companies such as Pinterest and Yahoo.

items.title: Meta joins $10b funding for Databricks
items.summary:
- Databricks has secured Meta as a new investor in a US$10 billion funding round.
- Investment part of one of the largest venture capital rounds, also featuring the Qatar Investment Authority.
- Meta's investment supports its development of Llama, an open-source large language model integrated into Databricks' AI offerings.
- Databricks has raised a total of US$14 billion to date, with an IPO expected within the next year.

items.title: Abu Dhabi launches $3.5b strategy for AI-driven gov’t
items.summary:
- Abu Dhabi has launched its Digital Strategy for 2025-2027 to become the world’s first fully AI-driven government.
- The initiative involves an investment of 13 billion dirham (US$3.5 billion) to automate government processes and implement over 200 AI-powered solutions.
- The strategy is projected to generate 24 billion dirham (US$6.53 billion) for the economy and create over 5,000 jobs by 2027, aligning with Emiratisation targets.
- Collaborative efforts include partnerships with the Advanced Technology Research Council and Mohamed bin Zayed University of Artificial Intelligence for research and skills development.

items.title: XPeng Aeroht launches 1,000-km island-flying project
items.summary:
- XPeng Aeroht has initiated a project for an innovative flying vehicle capable of traveling 1,000 km over islands.
- The flying car aims to enhance connectivity among islands and boost tourism within the region.
- This project is a part of XPeng's commitment to advancing urban air mobility solutions.

items.title: TSMC drives Taiwan stock exchange with 30% annual gain
items.summary:
- Taiwan’s Taiex index closed at 23,525.41 points on Jan. 22, with a 30% annual gain.
- The market’s capitalization increased by over NT$18 trillion (approximately US$547 billion).
- TSMC’s stock surged by 75.6%, reaching NT$1,135.00 (US$36.32).
- TSMC contributed roughly 70% of the Taiex’s market cap growth, with an increase of NT$12.68 trillion (US$405.76 billion).

items.title: Oracle to boost Abu Dhabi investment fivefold on AI, cloud
items.summary:
- Oracle plans to increase its investment in Abu Dhabi fivefold due to rising demand for AI and cloud services in the UAE.
- Currently operating two cloud regions in the UAE, Oracle will add 14 more regions globally, including in Neom, Saudi Arabia.
- The company will establish a sovereign cloud region in Bahrain and aims to train 350,000 individuals in the Middle East in AI and cloud infrastructure.

items.title: South Korea to build $1.7b AI center by 2027
items.summary:
- South Korea plans to establish a national AI computing center by 2027 with a budget of $1.7 billion (2.5 trillion won).
- The center is set to achieve a computing capacity of 1 exaflop.
- The government aims to acquire advanced GPUs by the end of this year to boost local AI research and development.
- This project is part of South Korea's ambition to enhance its AI infrastructure and become one of the top three global AI leaders.
- As of late 2023, South Korea had approximately 2,000 H100 GPUs compared to about 150,000 owned by Meta and Microsoft.

items.title: Jio, BlackRock invest $1.4m in new mutual fund venture
items.summary:
- Jio Financial Services (JFS) and BlackRock invested 117 crore rupees (US$1.404 million) in Jio BlackRock Asset Management.
- Each company subscribed to 5.85 crore rupees (US$70,200) equity shares at 10 rupees (US$0.12) per share on January 21.
- This follows a 50:50 partnership agreement aimed at launching wealth management and brokerage services in India.

items.title: This partnership could usher in a new wave of edge computing
items.author: Jimmy Qian, Tomoki Katada
items.summary:
[OWS (SG) signed an MOU with GFA to expand its high-performance computing leasing business across new markets.]
[The partnership aims to leverage both companies' strengths to capture the growing demand for AI and big data solutions.]
[OWS (SG) plans to establish a container-type data center in Japan using renewable energy and a fractional leasing model to cater to diverse customer needs.]

items.title: Instagram launches teen accounts for safety in South Korea
items.summary:
- Instagram has launched its Teen Accounts feature in South Korea for better protection of teenage users.
- The initiative limits exposure to explicit content and inappropriate interactions.
- Teen accounts (ages 14-18) are set to private by default; under 17s need parental consent for public access.
- Existing accounts under 17 will also be set to private unless guardian permission is granted.
- Additional safeguards include limiting direct messages, tags, and mentions to followed users.

items.title: Dubai telecoms operator to launch cloud, AI services
items.author: Jasim Al Awadi
items.summary:
- Dubai-based telecom operator du will launch sovereign cloud and AI services in the UAE starting July 2025.  
- In June 2024, du revealed plans to use Oracle Alloy for hyperscale cloud and sovereign AI services aimed at government and public sector clients.  
- The company faces competition from major tech firms like Microsoft, Amazon, and Google but intends to provide tailored, value-driven services for the UAE market.  
- The demand for sovereign cloud services is increasing globally due to regulatory requirements for data sovereignty and privacy.  
- The market is projected to grow from US$37 billion in 2023 to US$169 billion by 2028, indicating a 36% annual growth rate according to Gartner.

items.title: Saudi firm considers TikTok bid if Musk joins
items.author: Not given
items.summary:
- Saudi Arabia’s Kingdom Holding Company (KHC) is interested in investing in TikTok owned by ByteDance.
- The interest depends on whether Elon Musk or others pursue a bid for the app.
- This comes amid ongoing efforts in the US to find a buyer for TikTok after a previous ban was postponed by an executive order during Trump’s presidency.
- Musk, who owns the platform X and AI startup xAI, is considered a potential buyer, with KHC holding stakes in his companies.

items.title: Chinese esports firm secures $40m deal with Abu Dhabi
items.author: Mario Ho Yau-kwan
items.summary:
- Nip Group has signed a **five-year strategic agreement** with the Abu Dhabi Investment Office (ADIO).
- The company will establish its **headquarters in Abu Dhabi**, UAE.
- ADIO will provide up to **$40 million** in support over the next four years to enhance operations in areas including esports, creative studios, game publishing, event organization, and talent management.

items.title: Line launches apps to boost Asia’s blockchain adoption
items.summary:
- Line Next launched its first set of decentralized applications (DApps).
- The Mini Dapps include games, social media services, and Web3 content powered by Kaia, a Layer 1 blockchain developed with Kakao.
- A Dapp Portal was introduced for users to explore applications and trade NFTs.
- Initial offerings include “Captain Tsubasa -RIVALS-” and “Superz.”
- Line Next plans to roll out over 1,000 projects by the end of 2025.
- Line aims to expand Web3 adoption in Japan, Taiwan, and Thailand with its 200 million user base.

items.title: CreateAI eyes redemption with high-stakes pivot
items.author: Cheng Lu
items.summary:
- CreateAI, formerly TuSimple, is pivoting to the AI-generated content and video gaming market.
- TuSimple's fallout included delisting from Nasdaq and a sharp decline in valuation to below $8 billion.
- Cheng Lu was ousted as CEO in 2022 but was later reinstated.
- The pivot is met with skepticism from TuSimple's investors, questioning the relation between autonomous trucking and AI gaming.
- CreateAI aims to compete with companies like OpenAI and Elon Musk’s xAI in generating AI content without additional funding for the shift.

items.title: Crypto exchange Deribit hits $1.1t trading volume in 2024.
items.summary:
- Deribit reported a trading volume of US$1.1 trillion for 2024, up 95% from US$608 billion in 2023.
- The exchange recorded a peak 24-hour volume of US$14.8 billion on Nov. 12, following the US presidential election.
- Open interest reached US$48 billion on Nov. 28, coinciding with bitcoin prices exceeding US$100,000.
- Options trading increased by 99% in notional volumes, with spot trading up by 810% to US$7.6 billion.
- December 2024 was marked as the busiest trading month since November 2021, driven by Bitcoin and Ethereum ETFs and renewed interest in memecoins.
- Deribit relocated to Dubai, complying with the Virtual Assets Regulatory Authority and adopting the FATF Travel Rule for anti-money laundering.

items.title: SingPost appoints new group CFO
items.summary:
- Singapore Post appoints Isaac Mah as group CFO, effective immediately.
- The previous CFO was terminated amid a corporate investigation in 2024.
- Mah previously served as the CFO for SingPost’s Australian subsidiary, Freight Management Holdings (FMH).
- His original appointment was planned for December 2024 but was expedited.
- This change follows the dismissal of three senior executives due to negligence in handling a whistleblower report.

items.title: Glints reclaims revenue growth in 2024 with China plus one play
items.author: Oswald Yeo, Looi Qin En, Seah Ying Cong
items.summary:
- Glints faced a 4% revenue dip in 2023 and operational losses widened by 18% year on year.
- In 2024, revenue grew by 10% and losses narrowed by 22%, attributed to disciplined spending and efficiency improvements.
- The company aims to generate an operating profit from its talent solutions business by the end of 2025.
- Founded in 2013, Glints raised over US$82 million, with its last funding round of US$50 million in 2022.
- Revenue from Chinese companies increased by 2.6x from 2023 to 2024, as many seek growth in Southeast Asia due to a domestic slowdown in China.

items.title: OKX Ventures, TOP, Folius launch $10m Telegram growth hub
items.summary:
- OKX Ventures, TOP, and Folius have launched a $10 million growth hub for Telegram.
- The initiative aims to support projects that utilize Telegram in various sectors such as finance and gaming.
- This investment reflects a growing trend of integrating messaging platforms with business opportunities.

items.title: Asia’s tech investors with the highest exit rates
items.summary:
- The article provides insights into tech investors in Asia with high exit rates, which can indicate the likelihood of successful returns for startup founders.
- Exits can occur through mergers, secondary sales, or public listings, but high exit rates don’t necessarily reflect actual returns for investors.
- Later-stage investors generally have higher exit rates due to lower risk and greater liquidity, and startup exit ease may vary by country.
- The article emphasizes the importance of actual returns over exit rates for venture capital firms.

items.title: Americans scale China’s Great Firewall
items.summary:
- Americans flock to Xiaohongshu, a Chinese social media platform, amid TikTok ban discussions.
- TikTok CEO Shou Chew attended Trump's inauguration, highlighting the platform's political significance.
- Xiaohongshu offers a unique user experience emphasizing user engagement over advertising, distinguishing it from Western platforms.
- Temporary cultural exchange observed between American and Chinese social media users, raising questions about long-term engagement.
- Trump reverses EV policies from previous administration, with implications for the automotive industry.

items.title: EFishery employee denies entire company commits fraud
items.author: Elsa Vinietta
items.summary:
- An eFishery employee, Elsa Vinietta, addressed fraud allegations against the company on LinkedIn.
- She stated that the company's IoT, AI, and apps are legitimate products used by real farmers.
- Vinietta emphasized that not all employees are involved in any fraud, and many teams are not involved in financial transactions.
- eFishery is under investigation for allegedly inflating revenue by nearly $600 million.
- Allegations also suggest the company claimed to operate over 400,000 fish feeders, while actual numbers may be around 24,000.
- The issue escalated after the suspension of co-founders due to financial irregularities.

items.title: These are the most active investors in Japan’s startups
items.summary:
- A constantly updated list of the most active investors in Japan’s startups over the last two years.
- The firms are arranged by the number of deals completed, favoring early-stage investors.
- Only firms that have invested in three or more companies in Japan within the past two years are featured.

items.title: ByteDance denies claims of $12b AI investment plan
items.summary:
- ByteDance has denied claims of plans to invest significantly in AI chip procurement and model training outside of China.
- The Financial Times reported ByteDance aims to allocate 40 billion yuan (US$5.6 billion) to AI chips by 2025.
- Approximately US$6.8 billion was purportedly earmarked for overseas AI investments, especially utilizing Nvidia chips.
- A ByteDance representative stated that the reported figures and plans are incorrect, emphasizing that the company's investment strategy does not align with the cited numbers.

items.title: CATL shares drop 3.8% amid revenue, profit concerns
items.summary:
- Shares of CATL dropped by 3.8% on January 22, 2024.
- Company projected a revenue decline of 8.7% to 11.2% for 2024 and the slowest profit growth since 2019.
- The decline in shares is linked to the adjustment of product prices following lower raw material costs, especially lithium carbonate.
- CATL expects a net profit increase of between 11.1% and 20.1% in 2024.
- The company holds a 45.1% market share in the Chinese EV battery market and is considering a public listing in Hong Kong by 2025.
- Recent initiatives include the launch of an EV chassis and plans for international expansion.

items.title: YouTuber MrBeast joins bid to buy TikTok
items.author: Jimmy Donaldson
items.summary:
- Jimmy Donaldson, known as MrBeast, joins a group of American investors to purchase TikTok's US operations.
- This initiative aims to detach TikTok from its Chinese parent company, ByteDance, due to national security concerns.
- The investor group is led by Jesse Tinsley and includes various institutional investors and high-net-worth individuals.
- Details of the all-cash bid remain undisclosed, along with the identities of other investors.
- The law firm Paul Hastings represents the group, with Brad Bondi part of the legal team.
- No comments have been made by ByteDance, TikTok, or MrBeast's representatives regarding the bid.

items.title: Truecaller tackles AI voice cloning with new tech
items.summary:
- Truecaller AB addresses AI-generated voice cloning scams with new technology in its app.
- The app now analyzes callers' voices to differentiate between real and computer-generated voices.
- Truecaller is enhancing efforts using technology from its acquisition of CallHero Ltd. and exploring further AI acquisitions.
- Voice cloning scams have increased with the rise of generative AI tools, particularly impacting India, where Truecaller gets 70% of its revenue.
- Truecaller has 433 million monthly active users and anticipates 2024 revenue of around 1.85 billion krona (US$167 million).

items.title: Google invests $1b more in Anthropic, total reaches $2b
items.summary:
- Alphabet Inc.'s Google has invested an additional US$1 billion in Anthropic, raising its total investment to over US$2 billion.
- The funding aims to enhance Anthropic's computing capabilities and support its AI development efforts.
- Google has an existing business relationship with Anthropic, utilizing various online tools and services between them.
- Anthropic is recognized for its Claude language models and competes with OpenAI’s GPT series.
- Neither company has commented on the latest investment yet.

items.title: SoftBank shares rise on $100b AI deal with OpenAI, Oracle
items.summary:
- SoftBank's shares increased by 8.1% on Jan. 22, following a $100 billion AI investment announcement.
- The investment involves partnerships with OpenAI and Oracle for data centers and physical campuses.
- US President Donald Trump publicly announced the initiative, aiming to quickly deploy funds for AI development.
- Microsoft and Nvidia are also expected to contribute to the project.

items.title: SG startup launches AI tool to automate M&A processes
items.summary:
- Match.asia, a Singapore-based startup, has launched an AI tool named Navi.
- Navi automates various phases of the mergers and acquisitions (M&A) process including buyer research and data enrichment.
- The tool significantly reduces the time for outreach tasks, while also creating marketing materials like teasers and investment memos.
- Match.asia serves as a platform connecting buyers, sellers, and advisers involved in M&A transactions.

items.title: Zepto expands IPO plan to $1b amid rapid growth
items.summary:
- Zepto is expanding its planned IPO to between US$800 million and US$1 billion.
- Revised IPO includes US$300 million to US$400 million from secondary share sales and increased primary capital.
- CEO Aadit Palicha is engaging with major mutual funds for the public listing.
- Goldman Sachs and Morgan Stanley are leading the IPO efforts.
- Zepto has surpassed its goal of 700 dark store locations, currently having over 900, and plans to reach 1,000.
- The company raised US$350 million in November 2024, bringing cash reserves to US$1.4 billion.

items.title: How much should product designers be paid? This report has the data
items.summary:
- A report by Design Pay Asia details product designer salaries in Southeast Asia for 2024.
- Mid-level individual contributors in Indonesia saw a pay variance from 4 million to 768 million rupiah.
- Senior individual contributor salaries in Singapore range from S$44,000 to S$434,000, with a median of S$103,000.
- In Malaysia, director salaries range from 240,000 to 930,000 ringgit.
- Vietnam noted strong management premiums with salaries for managers ranging from 650 million to 2.4 billion dong.
- Thailand shows more compressed salary ranges and starts from 1 million baht for ICs at the lead level.

items.title: Samsung, SK hynix may shift production over US tariffs
items.summary:
- South Korean chipmakers Samsung Electronics and SK hynix are monitoring US trade policies under President Donald Trump, especially potential tariffs on China.
- They have invested over US$45 billion in semiconductor fabrication plants in the US.
- They may shift production if Trump enacts a proposed 60% tariff on Chinese goods.
- Samsung has already reduced its Xian factory output by 10%, and SK hynix is expanding its facilities in Korea.
- Despite challenges, both companies cannot shut down Chinese facilities due to the importance of the Chinese market.
- There may be a focus on high-value AI chips to offset the impact of tariffs.

items.title: Sequoia said to lead $300m fundraising for legal AI startup
items.summary:
- Sequoia Capital is reportedly in discussions to lead a US$300 million funding round for Harvey, a startup specializing in genAI tools for law firms.
- The funding round would value Harvey at US$3 billion.
- Harvey, officially known as Counsel AI Corp., has raised over US$200 million and was valued at US$1.5 billion in 2024.
- Existing investors include the OpenAI Startup Fund, Elad Gil, and Kleiner Perkins.

items.title: Indonesia close to deal to lift iPhone 16 ban, minister says
items.author: Rosan Roeslani
items.summary:
- Indonesia is close to an agreement with Apple to lift the iPhone 16 sales ban.
- The ban was due to Apple's failure to comply with local manufacturing regulations.
- A resolution is hoped to be achieved within one to two weeks.
- Discussions focus on Apple’s investment plan to meet local content requirements.
- Differing interpretations of local content requirement calculations have been acknowledged.

items.title: Coinbase CEO says Trump will fuel crypto investing
items.summary:
- Brian Armstrong, CEO of Coinbase, claims Trump’s presidency may boost crypto investments.
- Speaking at the World Economic Forum, he emphasized the potential influence of a US leader on the market.
- Armstrong noted that Trump could be a supporter of the crypto sector, as public endorsement can sway the industry.
- Legislative changes in Congress could also enhance investments in cryptocurrency, with bitcoin's recent peak linked to Trump's inauguration.

items.title: Stripe cuts 300 jobs in product, engineering, operations
items.summary:
- Stripe has announced a reduction of 300 jobs, approximately 14% of its workforce.
- The layoffs will affect teams across product, engineering, and operations.
- This move is part of a broader effort to streamline operations and gain profitability amid ongoing economic challenges.
- The company has previously cut jobs in 2022 and frozen hiring to manage costs more effectively.
